2. 3. To be fair, it's pretty much the entry point for new players, so the parceling out of goods is understandable; it lacks the urgency a survival-oriented game might have, though.

"There's such a severe lack of polish," is something I've uttered many, many times while playing this game.  Most of the bad things you may have read about it are probably true, as are most of the good things.  It's all going to boil down to what kind of gamer you are, and how much patience you have.  

I'm not exactly sure why a sandbox crafting/exploring game is so heavily formatted to be like an asian mmo.  Everything from the UI design, the grinding, the bad voice acting, to the game flow of doing all the quests in one area and getting sent to another and doing it all over again.  I spent years playing that sh*t, and PE doesn't win any points with me for using it.  The story is actually pretty decent, but is badly delivered because of the limitations of this format.  

Combat is clunky, at best.  Hitboxes are awful.  AWFUL.  From early in the game you'll be sent against absurd "bosses" that are usually impossible to kill at the time you receive these quests, or at the least without a great deal of grinding.  

I'm going to be blunt: the game isn't finished.  There are people who will argue that a tacked-on sequel-bait ending to the story technically means the game is done.  But not if it's still somewhere in a Beta state, if you ask me.  

And yet..... Somehow.....  The game has some bits of real magic in it.  

When you crash land on the planet, everything is new and vaguely terrifying.  Is that a tiny stegosaurus?  Is that a large, ferocious plush bunny?  Animals roam this MASSIVE totally destructible voxel landscape in multiple biomes, and apart from some weird fetish the devs obviously had for multiple eyes, all of the alien species are distinct from each other.  There's some REALLY good visual design here - it just happens to be badly optimized.  

The soundtrack is almost equally decent, although there are strange long periods of total silence because the game doesn't have enough ambient noise to compensate.  The game even has an integrated way to listen to your own music while you play.  

And the crafting.  Ohhhhhh the crafting.  We're not just talking about things you can make, and orient when building a colony.  We're talking a brilliant creation system where you fabricate basic parts, and then add material pixels however you like.  People have made all sorts of things in various categories, from flying pirate ships to weapons and armor from other games/films/real life.  I didn't dig too deeply since I stuck mostly with templates, but there's a lot here.  You can even go back and edit your creations later.  THIS is the meat of the game.  You run your colony, you hunt, farm, mine, and make stuff.  If that's not really your jam, the other elements of the game aren't going to do it for you.  

It doesn't quite last.  Not all of it.  At some point you've been to every biome.  You've seen every species and kicked its *ss.  You have so many raw materials you hardly ever need to harvest anymore.  Colony management can be just as clunky as most of the rest of the game.  At some point you'll just want to wrap up the story, and the story will delay you, usually in the form of travel, or grinding.  I'd estimate there's probably about 40 hours of story, and no, it doesn't end in a good way.  But if you like to make things and do all that other sandboxy stuff, you'll be entertained for much longer than that.  The game has alternating moments of "Wow, that's kind of amazing," and "Wtf happened?  Was an intern in charge of this?"  

There's some good stuff here, it's just that the devs bit off more than they could chew.  Word on the grapevine is they can't do any major code changes for PE, but they're taking on other projects to get funds for PE 2.  I look forward to it.

Planet Explorers stands proud as having the most creative freedom of any fleshed sandbox/survival game I've ever seen. From mining the terrain to collect resources, to crafting, colony creation and NPC recruitment, to being able to build your structures, weapons, armor, helicopters, jets, motorcycles and tanks, and even your very own Kitchen sink how you wish. 

PE utilizes a fully minable voxel world, along with a building and creation system that lets you bring your imagination to life. 

[b]*The voxel creation system.[/b] You can build weapons, vehicles, and even armor through a voxel creation system that let's you shape, color, and even texturize. Not only create them, but use them ingame for their determined roles.

[b]*Colony NPC recruitment.[/b] While there are plenty of games out there that have colony management, It's noteworthy to mention that recruiment in PE is about finding randomly generated npcs (aswell as pre-made npcs if you're playing story mode), that you can recruit into your colony for different roles. You can have them farm, gather resources, upgrade equipment, or patrol your colony to protect it from assailants. You may equip them as you wish, and even recruit them as followers to acompany on your journey. They all have unique appearences along with names (The names list is a bit short at the moment though..). They also come with their own sets of skills that you can have them train other colonists to have aswell.

[b]*Sandbox Creative Storymode.[/b] This is a big one.. Pathea has created a sandbox creation game that includes a storymode, without any cut functionality from adventure mode. Not only have they done this, but they've also gone and made it multiplayer. You can either play this on a public server, or host a private game with friends only!

[b]*NPC combat AI.[/b]
Monsters have been programmed to act according to what they are, rather than a default all-round AI slapped onto everything.. One creature will not engage the same as any other. Birds will keep distance, and swoop at their pray, or come in close temporary for a close range attack before swooping away..  Different bird creatures will even do this differently than others.. Not only do they have their own AI packages, but they also have their own animations specifically designed around them. 

Humanoid NPC's, followers and colonists, utilize the different tools and weapons you give them based on situation. For example, you can give a follower a sword and shield, and they will engage into melee, until their hp gets low, in which they will withdraw a distance from the enemy. If you've given them a ranged weapon aswell, they will draw their bow or gun and continue firing at the enemy from a distance, while they heal. If they have an axe in their inventory, they will aid you in cutting down trees.


If you have an inkling for design, and would love to see your very own creations have a purpose and use in a sandbox world, Planet Explorers is a must!

I bought Planet Explorers during a sale and did not touch it for a long time, but as soon as I started I just wanted to continue playing. There are not that much games that keep me playing long into the night.

I think this game is a highly underrated one. You can mostly compare it to Minecraft, but with Story mode and built using an older version of Unity Engine (but still looking good enough for me). 

Compared with "hardcore" survival games like 7 Days to Die, the survival aspect is not developed that much. You need to eat but not trink, you need to defend your camp but the game gives you strong weapons to do that. So it is not that "hardcore" but a lot more relaxing, and that's a good thing for me. You can enjoy exploring the land, hunt some animals, grow plants, build houses.... I like it.

The base building system is easily the best I ever saw in any game. You can choose between blocks or voxels to place, you can choose shape (round, triangle, cube etc...), size and texture of the blocks, you can place several at once, rotate them, you can undo your last few placed blocks... you can even save complete buildings as blueprints to quickly build a copy of it. Absolutely awesome.

And I'm not even starting with the ingame item creation editor. Do you want to design your own sword, gun, vehicle or helicopter? Do you want to customize it completely, pixel by pixel? You can, if you are creative enough (I'm not. :)) Every creation has some fixed parts that need to be placed (a sword needs a hilt), the rest is up to you. The damage of the sword comes from the material you choose (wood swords are worse than steel swords) and from the amount of material you use.

Combine this with NPCs that offer quests (you that you have a reason to do or craft something) you get a survival/exploration/base building game that offers great value for your money. I even like it more than Minecraft.

Sure, it could use some polishing. Unity 4 games should not drop below 30 frames (7 Days to Die Alpha 10-11 never did using this engine), there should be options to change color saturation (everything looks a bit bright and colorful for my taste) and programming could be a bit more smooth (first game start after PC is started is without problems and the game runs smooth, but if I quit the game and restart it, second start takes forever and ingame autosaves makes the game freeze for about 3 seconds. Short form: I'd give this game 8/10. There are a lot of games on Steam that are worse and more expensive.

When the developers announced the final release of Planet Explorers in 2016 I was angry.  I'd watched for years as this game went through development and though the progress wasn't as fast as any avid player would have liked, it was steady.  When the final version was released it still contained lots of half-finished features and bugs that had plagued the game throughout its development.  It seemed at the time like they were just throwing their hands up in the air and saying, "Screw it, let's put a wrapper on it and call it done."  That impression stayed with me until last night.

In [url=https://steamcommunity.com/app/237870/discussions/0/276237094331797388/]one comment thread[/url] I saw, one of the developers explained the situation:  They had wanted to continue development but the reality of the industry is that you have to have cash to do so. It also occurred to me after reading this that all through the development process the team had been more communicative than most development teams, not just posting dev logs but interacting with players and answering specific questions.  [b]My general impression is of a development team that loves this game as much as the players do and wanted just as badly as we did for it to be more than it ended up being.[/b]

Planet Explorers was an ambitious project that like so many other early access titles coulda, woulda, and shoulda but didn't.  Unlike many titles, however, I don't feel like it was because they didn't wanna.

I enjoy survival and crafting games, but the biggest problem most of them have is a total lack of purpose beyond simply not dying.

Too many times have I played such games and tossed them aside because it's just another "I'm here, because I'm here, because I'm here, because I'm here..." game. Pointless. Useless. Devoid of purpose or meaning. You may of course have that experience with this game too, if you wish to do so in Adventure mode, etc., but I prefer having some story.

Planet Explorers is not one of those pointless games. Playing through story mode once just racked up 96.8 hours of interesting and fun gameplay for me. 

While the dialogue and voice-overs themselves are bit on the amateurish side, the scope and breadth of the story as well as the concepts it seeks to convey are actually quite impressive even by triple-A title standards. Every effort you go to has a purpose. Has meaning. Right from the very beginning.

Constructive purpose, no less. This is important, as most of these kinds of game when they have a premise at all, it is based solely around defense against onslaught by one kind of ravening hoard or other after the apocalyptic downfall of all human civilization. Usually lame-ass zombies.

To be sure, Planet Explorers also takes place in a post-apocalyptic world. It just wasn't our apocalypse, or our world. Yet.

The story has a little bit of everything. Humor and meloncholy sadness. Drama and light-hearted fun. Treachery, betrayal, vengeance. The triumph of hard-earned peace and safety along with the horrors and loss of a senseless war no one involved can afford.

The thrill of real exploration and survival in a harsh environment with the odds stacked against you from the start. Not because of one single reason or agenda, but because half a dozen agendas or more and the chain of events they set in motion converge to create an unforseeable disaster from the viewpoint of any one group.

Why are you chopping down a tree with this dinky little starting cleaver? Because old Gerdy was in the lifeboat with you and didn't fair as well in the crash. Now you have to craft a shovel to dig up the medical supplies that got buried when you came down.

Why are you bothering to design your own armed aluminum hovercraft in the creations editor? Because you can sneeze a hole in wood and besides, you want your colonists to look badass when they fly four of them in during their show of force for the Puja in your efforts to bring them to the negotiation table for a peace treaty.

The game actually strikes a very good balance in the players themselves between the impulse to get more done so they can see more of the story and the knowledge that they must pace themselves, or be caught unprepared at a crucial turn of events in that storyline. A story which has a lot of twists and turns that most often really are very much an unexpected surprise, which is almost always based around a 'Big Thought' concept.

That's hard to find in nearly any genre of entertainment these days, much less a survival/sandbox/crafting game. This is stuff you usually only see handled in any way by hard and high-level Sci-Fi novels. And even then, only rarely are so many disparate such concepts brought into play for one story.

I would love to see the implied sequal made and would happily buy it in early access. 

These developers did this the way games should be done. They created a world and a story, then built a game around that, rather than building a game, THEN hiring writer to give it an excuse for existing, automatically hobbling any creativity or flexibility in the resulting story, or it's method of delivery.

I could be wrong about that, but even if I am, I must still credit them based on the grounds of their giving the writer(s) a great deal of freedom to tell an interesting story with their platform.

I mean really, when was the last time you actually CARED about your NPC colonists in a game? Knew them by name, personality and profession? Sorrowed if they died, beyond a mere loss in your colony's efficency or production or some such?

Story matters. Purpose in this kind of gameplay matters. Yes the game has some minor faults, but they are made less obvious and more minor because of the engaging story and sense of exploration. Easily overlooked.

Game developers who wonder why their games are being ripped apart in reviews by players on techincalities of gameplay mechanics need to look at this game and realize that the reason it's happening to them, is because they have offered the players nothing else by which to experience or evaluate their games.

An excellent addition to the sandbox adventure/miner sub-genre, Planet Explorers is, in a nutshell, what people who fell for the hype over StarForge were and still are looking for.

Where Starbound is basically Terraria in space, Planet Explorers has that same relationship with Minecraft but manages to be better. While Minecraft uses block-based voxels to construct its landscapes, Planet Explorers uses OpenCL. This enables the terrain to be just as malleable as that of Minecraft, but look a damn sight better. Though admittedly OpenCL, being a prototype, has a few bugs, one of which is that vehicles travelling at high speed over rough ground have a tendency to clip through the terrain as of 0.85. That said, the bugs present in the alpha of Planet Explorers, albeit slightly frustrating at times, are easily more forgivable than those in [i]certain AAA games[/i] (*stares viciously at EA and Ubisoft*) and barely put a scratch into the rest of the game.

Story mode is easily the best of the three game modes, the other two being Adventure (basically Minecraft Survival) and Build (creative mode). Beneath the magnificent visuals - not to mention the aliens themselves (which look [i]slightly[/i] less silly than those in Starbound) - there is a surprisingly well-crafted storyline with interesting lore and bright characters to explore. Item crafting in Story is tiered depending on how far you are into the story, with simple wooden equipment available for use at the start and more powerful armour and weapons being available for manufacture later on.

Speaking of crafting, Planet Explorers has what far too few games of this genre have in my honest opinion - a fleshed-out  and incredibly detailed item creation system that is easily mastered to boot. One can create a huge amount of useful, fully personalised items and vehicles - swords, guns, bikes, tanks, helicopters, boats and airborne dreadnoughts, to name but a few. Unfortunately, it is not possible to create custom tools or armour, and firearms are limited to pistols, assault rifles and laser rifles (but this might change soon). Nonetheless, Planet Explorers' powerful item creation system gives it a big leverage over other games of its genre.

To conclude: do I recommend this game? Of course I do. If you can forgive the glitches and bugs (take into account that this is an alpha, and not a fully released game yet), a wonderful sandbox adventure that has the potential to surpass even Minecraft in its scope awaits the lenient.

*LONG load times: Regardless of which mode you play on (Story, Adventure, Build), you'll find yourself having to fast-travel around the large maps provided. However, each and every time you fast travel, the game has to load in. I've experienced loading times as long as 5 minutes or more and in worst case scenarioes, even had to reload an autosave after the game froze \ crashed.

*"Story" Mode needs more STORY and character development: I cannot stress enough that there needs to be more STORY in Story Mode. When you first begin Story Mode, it will give you an introduction cutscene showing you and a group of colonists travel the stars on board of a starship. Only moments later, some kind of event triggers and you and your shipmates get shot down and crash land on an alien planet, where you have to survive on. 

The story then thrusts itself upon you as you pick up the pieces. The characters that you meet say that they have met you on board the ship you came in from, but use the stupid excuse that, "Oh you must have hit your head and forgot who I am" thing, over and over again. I'm sorry "Gerdy" and "Dr. Allen," but I don't know who the HELL you guys are, as the game never gave me much of a chance to meet you prior to this event.

*The voice acting is TERRIBLE: After the introduction cutscene in Story Mode, you'll quickly notice that after talking with the first NPC you see how robotic and how stale and flat-toned the voice acting is. Most people you talk with in conversation don't even sound like a human in real life voiced them; i.e. they sound like a voice similar to Microsoft Sam. It honestly sounds like the voice actors recorded in the bathroom stall at their studio \ home. 

This is an issue because with a game focused on "Story" and "Character Development," it's really hard to get immersed with all these different characters you meet along the way with the dialog so bland and boring. Either hire more talented voice actors or allow us to read text-only dialog, like in Adventure Mode. 

*The same BGM (background music) over and over: You can count with one hand the amount of BGMs that are in this game, as there aren't many to go with. It's not so bad at first, but after a few hours you begin to resent the music so much that you eventually disable the music altogether. 

*The majority of the questing is BORING: If you've played an MMORPG before, you know the routine: go from Point A to Point B, collect and kill stuff, and turn the quest in. If that's something that interests you, though, then this game will be great for you, as there are a PLETHORA of these type of quests.

*Monster fighting is BORING: Enemies come in 2 varieties, just 2: Charge and attack you straight on with maybe 1-2 abilities, or ARMAGEDDON TERRORS that shoot laser beams and missiles at you. 

The enemies that just charge and attack you may have some abilities that also knock you around literally like a rag doll. Fight with enemies that use knockback are as follows: hit them a few times, dodge roll back, hit them a few times, etc. Repeat this and you win.

Then there are some enemies that are like if Godzilla fused with a Gundam and proceed to start a mini-war with you. If you're playing on Normal like I did, they a virtually impossible to kill, unless you have great gear, a vehicle with weapons on it, or an hour or two in real life to spare taking it down.

That's not even to mention that one of the only "difficult" parts about the enemies is that some of them can take A LOT of damage, e.i. they are damage sponges. 

*Skill tree system extremely limits to what you can or can't do: In Story Mode, you don't have the opportunity to use the skill tree system as you are with Adventure Mode, so when I saw the option, I thought to myself, "Oh cool! This should make the game more fun!" ..... It didn't and made it pretty frustrating at times.

The skill tree system in Planet Explorers uses skill points that you can allocate to different skills, such as mining / chopping faster, gaining more materials doing those, doing more damage with weapons, etc. You get these skill points by killing monsters(2-8 SP each), mining(1-2 each node), chopping trees down(1-2 each tree), etc.

Maybe you think to yourself, "Well, the map is a pretty big place to just be walking around only, so I'll go get the parts and make a vehicle to ride around in!" You take the time to gather everything you need, maybe even pimp out a custom vehicle ride in the vehicle creator. When you try to "Export" the vehicle into the game, though, you'll quickly realize that you need a specific SKILL to even Export something from the creator to in-game (which will cost you hundreds of skill points to farm up to that point). So say you farmed up everything and got the skill to Export the vehicle to the game. You place down your sweet ride and you're about to ride it, but OH WAIT! You need the specific skill to even DRIVE the damn thing (costs another 90 skill points). You see where I'm getting at?

To even do the most basic gameplay functions requires you to unlock specific skills within the different skill trees. Can't use your new tool or weapon? Get the skill for it. Can't use a specific type of building block or building block shape? Get the skill for it. So on, and so on.

I have played many sandbox survival games for many years and this is the first time I've seen such a system as appalling as this system. If you're playing this game on Adventure Mode, make sure to uncheck this broken system and just stick with the default.

*Food and sleep meter doesn't have much of an impact to gameplay: I never once felt, during my 30+ hours of playing, that the food and sleep meters had any significant consequence against me. I never had the thought that, "Well, my food meter is almost depleted. I better go eat something before I starve to death." There's doesn't seem to be any weight or impact of the gameplay with the current food / sleep meters, other than just losing some stats temporarily.

*NPC Followers and NPC colonists never shut up: This is just a minor point, but every time either an NPC follower or NPC colonists is in need of something, they will vocally tell you that they are in need of it. (I.e. "I need more ammo!" or "I'm too sleepy to work!"). They will NEVER SHUT UP about it until you give them what they want, much like a toddler does when they want a toy real bad. 

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
I could go on and on about many different aspects about Planet Explorers, but the point I'm trying to come across is that this game needs MORE work on it. 

There's lots of potential in this game, such as the in-game object / weapon / vehicle customization system (very easy to learn, fun to use), and the NPC followers with the colony feature (colonists can farm crops and material for you, base defense, building stuff, etc), but everything else around it needs refinement.

If what I said above didn't dissuade you, as a customer, in your interest to this game then I suggest you at least download the demo of this game before purchasing and find out yourself.
